Award.AwardTitle: Structural properties of random tree models and their applications in network flows, brain circulation networks and statistical physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main aim of this proposal is a systematic mathematical study of a number of random network models arising from applications in computer science, biology and statistical physics, understanding dynamics on these network models, and developing mathematical methodology to glean information from real world networks. Using branching process embeddings and local weak convergence techniques, we propose to develop a set of robust tools that can be used to analyze one of the most important family of network models (the attachment family) which arises in a diverse range of applications. These mathematical techniques will give information on the asymptotics of not only local functionals such as degree distributions but global functionals such as the maximal degree and the spectral distribution of (random) adjacency matrices. Using continuous time branching process techniques we also propose to analyze models of network flow and first passage percolation, in order to understand the effect of disorder on the geometry of random network models and the propagation of congestion across edges in flow carrying networks. Preliminary computations suggest that for a wide array of models, macroscopic order emerges from microscopic rules of transport as the size of the network increases, and the project will attempt to understand this phenomenon and explore connections between these models and stable age distribution theory and the Malthusian rate of growth of branching process models in biology. New models of random trees motivated by statistical physics and biology will also be studied wherein using random walk constructions and conditioned branching processes, we aim to understand the scaling limits of such models. Finally we propose to develop mathematical methodology to analyze, understand and quantify sources of variation in the structure of real world complex networks such as trees arising as blood circulatory networks in the brain.


Over the last few years the availability of empirical data on many real world networks including social networks, data transmission networks such as the Internet and various biological networks, has stimulated an explosion in the array of mathematical models proposed to understand these networks. Researchers in a wide array of fields are interested in understanding properties of such networks, the evolution and change of such networks over time, as well as the dynamics of various processes on these networks such as transporting flow or traffic through these networks and epidemic models on these networks. An understanding of the behavior of these mathematical models would allow practitioners to glean important information and insight about such processes in the real world, ranging from the design of more efficient networks, understanding the factors that influence the rate of spread of congestion of flow processes or other dynamics through the network, to the significant factors that contribute to the actual emergence of the structure of the network itself. A mathematical analysis of such problems leads to interesting connections between these models and wide areas of mathematical probability including branching process models in biology and random fractals. The aim of this project is to develop mathematical methodology to understand properties of such network models and in particular understand what happens when the system size grows large. At the same time the project will also develop techniques to accurately understand data arising from various biological networks such as vascular networks in the brain and the factors that significantly affect functional properties of such networks. The techniques developed will be of use to a wide community of researchers, and we anticipate that the project will foster interdisciplinary collaborative projects with both national and international research groups and facilitate the training of students and expose them to this rapidly emerging field of research.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main theme of this proposal was a systematic mathematical study of network models arising from applications in social networks, computer science, biology and statistical physics. This included understanding models of dynamics on these networks, including the flow of information between entities in the network, as well as understanding how microscopic interactions between individuals in the network leads to the emergence of macroscopic structure such as heavy tailed degree distribution or small world distance scaling between individuals. From the applied perspective, this included developing mathematical methodology to glean information from real world networks such as blood circulatory networks in the brain and Twitter event networks. 


Using continuous time branching process embeddings, we developed a robust set of mathematical techniques  to understand asymptotics, in the large network limit,  for the optimal flow of information in network models where each edge has an inherent measure of congestion or length. Statistics of the optimal path between vertices including the total cost of the path as well as Hopcount, namely the number of edges in the path were derived. In many applications including understanding macroscopic properties of data transmission networks such as the Internet, one observes shortest path trees and then uses various functionals of these trees to understand properties of the underlying network. Asymptotics for the degree distribution of shortest path trees for various network models and their connection to the original underlying network were derived. Connections between these questions and models of epidemic or disease transmission through networks was explored.  The above collection of questions falls in what is sometimes called the weak disorder regime in statistical physics, where the weight of the path is measured by the sum of edges on the path. Strong disorder regimes, where the optimality of the path is measured by the maximal edge weight, leads to one of the most fundamental objects in combinatorial optimization, the minimal spanning tree. The first step in understanding asymptotics of this object on network models, is a detailed understanding of the so called critical regime of the model, where a giant connected component in the network emerges via mergers of small connected components, as the edge density increases beyond a critical point. General theory was developed to understand scaling limits of maximal connected components in this critical regime. Asymptotic negligibility conditions were derived under which these maximal components converged to a universal scaling limit. Further, new families of random fractals were derived as limits of maximal components, in regimes where the underlying degree distribution of the network has heavy tails, leading to a dense collection of hub vertices in these limiting random objects. 


One of the most popular families of network models used in applications (the preferential attachment family) was studied and mathematical techniques developed to understand asymptotic properties of the model and its variants. Associated continuous time branching process embeddings were used to develop theory that gave information on all local functionals (including local neighborhoods and degree distribution) as well as a wide array of global functionals such as maximal degree distributions, spectral distribution of associated (random) adjacency matrices and height of these random objects. Variants of this model were used by the PI and collaborators to understand new phenomenon observed in social networks including the emergence of densely connected nodes whose degree contributed to a positive fraction of the entire edge density of the network. Probabilistic techniques were developed to understand the effect of change point when the model driving the evolution...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The main theme of this proposal was a systematic mathematical study of network models arising from applications in social networks, computer science, biology and statistical physics. This included understanding models of dynamics on these networks, including the flow of information between entities in the network, as well as understanding how microscopic interactions between individuals in the network leads to the emergence of macroscopic structure such as heavy tailed degree distribution or small world distance scaling between individuals. From the applied perspective, this included developing mathematical methodology to glean information from real world networks such as blood circulatory networks in the brain and Twitter event networks. Using continuous time branching process embeddings, we developed a robust set of mathematical techniques to understand asymptotics, in the large network limit, for the optimal flow of information in network models where each edge has an inherent measure of congestion or length. Statistics of the optimal path between vertices including the total cost of the path as well as Hopcount, namely the number of edges in the path were derived. In many applications including understanding macroscopic properties of data transmission networks such as the Internet, one observes shortest path trees and then uses various functionals of these trees to understand properties of the underlying network. Asymptotics for the degree distribution of shortest path trees for various network models and their connection to the original underlying network were derived. Connections between these questions and models of epidemic or disease transmission through networks was explored. The above collection of questions falls in what is sometimes called the weak disorder regime in statistical physics, where the weight of the path is measured by the sum of edges on the path. Strong disorder regimes, where the optimality of the path is measured by the maximal edge weight, leads to one of the most fundamental objects in combinatorial optimization, the minimal spanning tree. The first step in understanding asymptotics of this object on network models, is a detailed understanding of the so called critical regime of the model, where a giant connected component in the network emerges via mergers of small connected components, as the edge density increases beyond a critical point. General theory was developed to understand scaling limits of maximal connected components in this critical regime. Asymptotic negligibility conditions were derived under which these maximal components converged to a universal scaling limit. Further, new families of random fractals were derived as limits of maximal components, in regimes where the underlying degree distribution of the network has heavy tails, leading to a dense collection of hub vertices in these limiting random objects. One of the most popular families of network models used in applications (the preferential attachment family) was studied and mathematical techniques developed to understand asymptotic properties of the model and its variants. Associated continuous time branching process embeddings were used to develop theory that gave information on all local functionals (including local neighborhoods and degree distribution) as well as a wide array of global functionals such as maximal degree distributions, spectral distribution of associated (random) adjacency matrices and height of these random objects. Variants of this model were used by the PI and collaborators to understand new phenomenon observed in social networks including the emergence of densely connected nodes whose degree contributed to a positive fraction of the entire edge density of the network. Probabilistic techniques were developed to understand the effect of change point when the model driving the evolution of the network undergoes an abrupt change.
